intro: Gastrolobium verticillatum, commonly known as the clustered wattle, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of about 1 to 2 meters, featuring narrow, grey-green leaves arranged in whorls of three to five. The plant produces yellow flowers in late winter to early spring, which are borne in dense clusters at the ends of the branches. It is adapted to dry, sandy soils and is often found in heathlands and open woodlands. The species is part of the Fabaceae family, which includes many legumes known for their nitrogen-fixing abilities.
